Situation1: The partner is grieving the sudden loss of a close family member.
Situation2: They must verify that a high-rise hospital project fully complies with all safety regulations to prevent life-threatening hazards.
Story: I sat on the edge of the bed, my phone buzzing with urgent messages from the construction site. My partner lay beside me, eyes red and distant, barely speaking since the call about his brother. He needed me—needed my arms around him, my words, my presence. But the hospital project was at a critical stage. The city inspector was coming in two hours, and I was the only one who could walk the team through the final safety checks. If I missed something, lives could be at risk. My mind raced with checklists and code requirements, but my heart ached for him, for the way his hand reached for mine in the dark. I felt torn in two, the weight of his grief pressing against the responsibility I owed to hundreds of future patients. I wanted to be everything he needed, but the world outside our room demanded a different kind of vigilance. My chest tightened as I stared at the clock, knowing I couldn’t be in both places at once.
